title: Fabian Picardo re-elected chief minister of Gibraltar
text:
Fabian Picardo, chief minister of Gibraltar | Jack Taylor/Getty Images Fabian Picardo re-elected chief minister of Gibraltar Picardo secures third term with a socialist-liberal coalition.

Fabian Picardo will be responsible for steering Gibraltar safely through Brexit after being re-elected as chief minister of The Rock.

This is the third time Picardo has won elections in Gibraltar as the candidate of a coalition between his party, the Gibraltar Socialist Labour Party, and the Liberal Party. This alliance obtained 52.5 percent of the vote and secured 10 of the 17 seats at stake in the Gibraltar parliament.

Picardo will lead the U.K. territory at the southern tip of the Iberian Peninsula for the next four years.

In a speech after the results were announced Friday, he said this would be the last election he contends.

“Our main role in these coming four years will be to sail this nation of ours safely through the uncharted waters of our departure from the European Union,” he said. “We will sail our people securely through every potential variation of that process even its potential cancellation.”

He added: “We have set the foundations to ensure Gibraltar will reach the safe harbour that we want for our nation with an enduring partnership with the United Kingdom, a partnership well beyond colonialism, a relationship recognized internationally as beyond colonialism.”

Ahead of the election, Picardo told POLITICO in an interview that he decided to bring the vote forward after Boris Johnson became U.K. prime minister to ensure a new government would be in place in case there was a no-deal Brexit.

The center-right party Gibraltar Social Democrats won 25.6 percent of the vote, which gave the camp led by Keith Azopardi six seats in Gibraltar’s parliament.

Marlene Hassan Nahon, leader of the left-wing Together Gibraltar party, won 20.5 percent of the vote and one seat.

Turnout was 70.84 percent.
description: Picardo secures third term with a socialist-liberal coalition.
